awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Casey Rodriguez is "Nonlinear Dispersive Equations." The host institution for the fellowship is Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Gigliola Staffilani.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit. The works completed with the support of DMS-1703180 include:

  • classifying the dynamics of symmetric solutions to a system of geometric, nonlinear, wave equations (energy critical wave maps equations) with threshold energy, below which one has global existence for all time above which one can have finite-time breakdown,
  • constructing and classifying the dynamics of symmetric solutions to the energy critical wave maps equations that break down in finite time with a prescribed regular part via the bubbling off of a harmonic map (joint with J. Jendrej and A. Lawrie),
  • proving the local well-posedness in Sobolev spaces for a promising model of relativistic viscous fluids (joint with F. Bemfica, M. Disconzi and Y. Shao),
  • studying stretch-limited catenaries; elastic strings under the force of gravity where the stretch can be maximized or minimized,
  • studying the dynamic problem of a straight, tensile, stretch-limited string with precisely one growing segment where the stretch is maximized.

Broader impacts. For the duration of this grant, the PI served on the Diversity and Community Building Committee at MIT. He was also an undergraduate advisor for four students double majoring in math and mentored one undergraduate student as part of the Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program at MIT. The PI also was a co-organizer for the MIT PDE/Analysis Seminar and for a PDE/Analysis Reading Seminar. He collaborated with the Department of Mathematics to publish his complete course materials for Math 18.100A on the MIT Open Course Ware platform. Finally, the PI organized MIT funded ``mentoring dinners" that fostered interaction and mentoring between Assistant Professors and Postdoctoral Fellows in the Department of Mathematics. His efforts at MIT for the duration of this grant were recognized by the 2020 Infinite Kilometer Award; an award presented by the School of Science annually to researchers who are exceptional contributors to their communities.


Last Modified: 10/24/2022
Modified by: Casey P Rodriguez

classifying the dynamics of symmetric solutions to a system of geometric, nonlinear, wave equations (energy critical wave maps equations) with threshold energy, below which one has global existence for all time above which one can have finite-time breakdown,
constructing and classifying the dynamics of symmetric solutions to the energy critical wave maps equations that break down in finite time with a prescribed regular part  via the bubbling off of a harmonic map (joint with J. Jendrej and A. Lawrie),
proving the local well-posedness in Sobolev spaces for a promising model of relativistic viscous fluids (joint with F. Bemfica, M. Disconzi and Y. Shao),
studying stretch-limited catenaries; elastic strings under the force of gravity where the stretch can be maximized or minimized, 
studying the dynamic problem of a straight, tensile, stretch-limited string  with precisely one growing segment where the stretch is maximized.


Broader impacts. For the duration of this grant, the PI served on the Diversity and Community Building Committee at MIT. He was also an undergraduate advisor for four students double majoring in math and mentored one undergraduate student as part of the Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program at MIT.
